message: Most days I just pop out to the shops, which is death by a thousand paper cuts for my food budget
maruchan noodle bowls to be specific
aka ocean in a bowl
Salads with meat and cheese. Mmm.
I love firing up a roast on the weekends and then enjoying it throughout the week. Nutritious and delicious!
I hate soggy sandwiches.. I used to bring everything to work and make the sandwiches there.
But the people that would stay late couldn't keep their fingers out of my shite... So I stopped doing that. haha
ramen

just make them like they were for school except you are doing them not mom :)
Was wondering if anyone has good ideas for cheap meals that can be prepared in advance and are suitable for work
do you prepare them in the morning, the night before..?
2 ham sandwiches prepared while I watch whatever is next in my Netflix streaming queue
is that like freeze-dried instant noodles?
I cut everything up and it lasts a couple of days.
good call, I had ham today
I usually choose from one of a few places in downtown to visit, luckily it's not too far to drive
@Matthias I think you're onto a winner there, that sounds genius... I wonder if frozen stew could survive the 50 minute commute
The office is out in the countryside and within walking/cycling distance there is only one small shop. I often get a baguette and ham/cheese/etc or a flapjack and some soup.
I like Hummus, baguette bread and tomatoes.
just add water
my 30 mins doesnt allow me to do much!

Prepare sandwiches on Sunday and freeze them till the morning you will eat them. Don't put sauce/dressing on till lunch. Leftovers in tupperware. Soups, stews, and chili are especially great for that. Frozen dinners / pizzas.
@Aussiewebmaster I went to boarding school :P
Oatmeal with Peanut Butter + Jelly and a bit of almond milk 15 bucks and you'll probably get thirty meals out of it.
I tried to use Let's Lunch http://letslunch.com/ but I guess my status is not interesting enough or not enough people in my area (Sunnyvale) use it.

We (my team and I) normally just pop out and grab something ranging from supermarkets and bakery goodies to Indian market chicken tikka rolls and fast food; occasionally we'll be particularly hungry and actually go randomly have a sit down meal at a local establishment; take a 90 minute lunch and claw back some of the crazy overtime!
PBJ and milk or ham/tuna/roast beef etc sandwich
Have three great local places within 5 minute walking distance --- sandwiches, mexican, and a great burger place.
Whatever you do, don't eat sandwiches every single day. I put on a fair few pounds when I started a game development job and ate nothing else.

This is a great topic to chat about. I find myself eating out a lot now, especially moving into a more demanding job and reading taking up most of my time. I'd like to go back to what I did before: pre-plan all of my meals.

Canned Tuna, Salmon, Beans are really good. You can easily get salsa, some beans and tuna into a wrap. This can be done cold with little preparation. Wraps of cold meats, cheese and salad works.
rice, beans, and salsa in a tupperware, microwave it at work
add vegetables for excitement
@AroonUp my favourite thing to do with canned tuna is pasta, veg (peas and sweetcorn for me), mayo, makes a delicious cold salad
... or a hot one if you're impatient

I'm lucky enough to work for a place that provides lunch and dinner everyday so i don't have to worry about it anymore. However, before my current job I always tried to make simple things like fried rice or pasta for dinner and eat leftovers for lunch.
I usually get some nice soup and a piece of baguette w/ ham/cheese from the Whole Foods nearby.
lololo
Just in case someone wants to give www.letslunch.com a try, invitation codes: SCA253D9C3 SC2624871D - So far this has been ideal to meet new and interesting people without loosing time.

When I was working in the middle of a (relatively) large city, I would go out with coworkers almost every day. Now that I'm in a much smaller city and trying to save money, I usually just bring a sandwich. Luckily for me, I'm not a big lunch eater, so it's easy for me to just have something smaller.
